title: Books
text:
Links to books

R Markdown: The Definitive Guide

Absolute Must.

R Markdown Cookbook
R Cookbook, 2nd Edition
R Companion to Real Econometrics
R For Data Science
Moderndive: Statistical Inference via Data Science

Also see Learn the tidyverse which provides links to a few more related topics.

STAT 545: Data Wrangling, Exploration, and Analysis with R

This site is about everything that comes up during data analysis except for statistical modelling and inference.

R for Researchers: An Introduction
R Graphics Cookbook, 2nd edition
What They Forgot to Teach You About R: The stuff you need to know about R, besides statistical analysis.
R Programming for Data Science
Hands-On Programming with R
R Packages (2e)
R Books

“A curated list of books about different aspects and applications of R programming language and an attempt to modernize R Books in a more user friendly way.”

Bookdown: Write HTML, PDF, ePub, and Kindle books with R Markdown

This leads to another list of books that are helpful for authoring books.
Here is an archive that lists even more books from bookdown
The actual bookdown book by Yihui Xie

RMarkdown for Scientists
Exploratory Data Analysis with R
Telling Stories with Data With Applications in R
Advanced R

Yeah right. One day I’ll read this. No I won’t.

The Effect: An Introduction to Research Design and Causality
Foundations of Statistics with R
Learning statistics with R: A tutorial for psychology students and other beginners
Learning Statistics with R
R for Psychological Science
Mastering Shiny
The Data Preparation Journey: Finding Your Way With R

This appears to be a work in progress but there’s a lot that seems useful.

Social Science Theory

This is more of like a list of many social science theories.

title: Methods
text:
Resources: How to Methods
An unorganized list of links to resources that have helped, are helpful, or might be helpful. I have not curated this yet to be organized into different methods.

psyTeachR

This resource is incredible. Just check it out.
“The psyTeachR team at the University of Glasgow School of Psychology and Neuroscience has successfully made the transition to teaching reproducible research using R across all undergraduate and postgraduate levels. Our curriculum now emphasizes essential ‘data science’ graduate skills that have been overlooked in traditional approaches to teaching, including programming skills, data visualisation, data wrangling and reproducible reports. Students learn about probability and inference through data simulation as well as by working with real datasets.”
“This website contains our open materials for teaching reproducible research. See our GitHub for open data and code.”

Growth Curve Modeling
Graphical & Latent Variable Modeling

Pretty good intro/information on Structural Equation Modeling (e.g., latent variable modeling) by Michael Clark (I don’t know him).

title: Resources
text:
This is continuously being updated. So far it is a list of resources I have found that is either useful or potentially useful. Some of these I have used so often, others I have not ever utilized but saved anyway. I’m updating and organizing this page as you read this.
